repnme.cdata!:
Brazil - Ecosystem Restoration of Riparian
            Forests in Sao Paulo Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Ecosystem Restoration of
            Riparian Forests in Sao Paulo Project for Brazil were as
            follows: outcome was moderately unsatisfactory, risk to
            development outcome was moderate, Bank performance was
            moderately unsatisfactory, and Borrower performance was
            moderately satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: in
            land or forest management projects that aim to induce a
            change in land use practices and scaling up, it is important
            to gain an understanding of the motives different types of
            landholders have to adopt and maintain such practices in
            addition to technical dimensions of restoration. In this
            case, the project documented some comparative evidence on
            the cost and effectiveness of alternative riparian forest
            restoration technologies that may be of use to future
            restoration efforts. Consistency between the objectives
            statements and the scale of investments and associated
            indicators is essential to avoid incongruities between
            investment strategy and project intent. In this case the
            project's official objectives were stated in terms of
            ambitious global environment objectives. Working through
            multiple institutional players can enhance policy and
            operational outcomes but it requires that mechanisms are
            developed to formalize institutional partnership with
            clearly defined common targets and timetables to reduce
            delays. Such mechanisms need to be agreed among all partners
            upfront and tailored to their own bureaucratic, managerial
            and operational structures. Early consensus on coordination
            of monitoring and evaluation (M and E) between institutions
            and sectors within government is crucial in order to ensure
            alignment of objectives and targets and to achieve the flow
            of M and E data between entities. Incompatibilities between
            the operational structures of the two agencies led to
            bottlenecks in information flows that made it difficult for
            the project management team to detect and respond to issues
            as they arose and provide timely feedback to other project
            executing entities.

repnme.cdata!:
Brazil's experience with payments for
            environmental services

abstracts.cdata!:
Since 2006, there has been an explosion
            of Payments for Environmental Services (PES) projects in
            Brazil, as well as efforts to pass PES laws at federal,
            state, and municipal levels. Even in this short period, an
            extraordinarily rich range of experiences has developed,
            with examples of the application of PES at a variety of
            scales, ranging from microwatersheds to entire states; in a
            variety of contexts, from remote forest frontier areas to
            the periurban fringe of megacities like São Paulo; and using
            a variety of approaches, using direct payments by users,
            sales to regulated and voluntary carbon markets, government
            funding, and mixes of these approaches. In this paper, we
            provide an overview of Brazilian PES efforts to date, and
            attempt to extract some initial lessons.

repnme.cdata!:
Experiences of payments for environmental
            services in Brazil

abstracts.cdata!:
Since 2006, there has been an explosion
            of Payments for Environmental Services (PES) projects in
            Brazil, as well as efforts to pass PES laws at federal,
            state, and municipal levels. Even in this short period, an
            extraordinarily rich range of experiences has developed,
            with examples of the application of PES at a variety of
            scales, ranging from micro watersheds to entire states; in a
            variety of contexts, from remote forest frontier areas to
            the peri-urban fringe of megacities like Sao Paulo; and
            using a variety of approaches, using direct payments by
            users, sales to regulated and voluntary carbon markets,
            government funding, and mixes of these approaches. This book
            provides detailed case studies of the main Brazilian PES
            efforts to date.

repnme.cdata!: O Projeto Mina d'Água em São Paulo, Brasil

abstracts.cdata!:
This paper points out that Payment for
            Environmental Services (PSA) was conceived as a new
            management tool, additional to the existing command and
            control, in order to facilitate the restoration and special
            conservation of native vegetation and the conversion of
            conventional models for production systems more sustainable
            in areas of environmental importance. In this context, the
            state of São Paulo decided to develop a statewide program of
            PSA, and the Mine Water Project pioneered the example that
            should provide information to guide the continuity of
            actions, especially regarding the arrangements for the
            implementation and formatting of upcoming projects.

docna.cdata!: O Projeto Mina d'Água em São Paulo, Brasil

display_title.display_title:
O Projeto Mina d'Água em São
            Paulo, Brasil

repnme.cdata!:
O Projeto Produtor de Água na bacia
            hidrográfica PCJ em São Paulo, Brasil

abstracts.cdata!:
This working paper points out that the
            state of São Paulo is planning to make the Payment for
            Environmental Services (PSA) an important part of its
            combination of policies to solve environmental problems. The
            Producer of Water in the PCJ (PoA-PCJ) is the pilot project
            of the PSA in the state where the strategies are designed,
            tested and evaluated as an important subsidy for
            larger-scale programs in the state.
